results.bill_title: Relating to the collection of consumer debt incurred by certain individuals as a result of identity theft.

findings.statement: The bill prohibits creditors, debt collectors, or third-party debt collectors from attempting to collect a consumer debt from a victim of identity theft if certain documentation is provided.

quotes.text: A creditor, debt collector, or third-party debt collector may not attempt to collect a consumer debt or a portion of a consumer debt from a consumer if the consumer provides...a criminal complaint alleging the commission of an offense under Section 32.51, Penal Code...

findings.statement: The bill requires debt collectors to cease collection efforts and notify others if they receive notice that a debt is a result of identity theft.

quotes.text: shall immediately cease efforts to collect the disputed debt or disputed portion of the debt from the victim of identity theft

shall send to each person who has previously received a report relating to that debt from the creditor, debt collector, or third-party debt collector notice that the debt is disputed under this section and not collectible from the victim of identity theft

findings.statement: The bill allows creditors to enforce security interests but prohibits collection of deficiencies from identity theft victims.

quotes.text: may, if the disputed debt or disputed portion of the debt is secured by tangible personal property, enforce the security interest under Chapter 9, Business & Commerce Code, but may not collect or seek to collect any deficiency from the victim of identity theft

findings.statement: Creditors can file suit if they believe a consumer falsely claims identity theft.

quotes.text: If a creditor, debt collector, or third-party debt collector has a good faith reason to believe that a consumer has disputed a consumer debt or portion of a consumer debt under this section based on a material misrepresentation that the consumer is a victim of identity theft, the creditor, debt collector, or third-party debt collector may file suit in a court of competent jurisdiction to collect the debt from the consumer.

findings.statement: The bill provides that a creditor, debt collector, or third-party debt collector may not attempt to collect a consumer debt from a consumer if the consumer provides evidence of being a victim of identity theft.

quotes.text: A creditor, debt collector, or third-party debt collector may not attempt to collect a consumer debt or a portion of a consumer debt from a consumer if the consumer provides: (1) a criminal complaint alleging the commission of an offense under Section 32.51, Penal Code, or a substantially similar federal law or law in another state, for which the consumer was a victim, accompanied by a statement identifying the consumer debt or the portion of consumer debt that resulted from the offense;

findings.statement: The bill requires creditors to cease collection efforts immediately upon receiving notice that a debt is disputed due to identity theft.

quotes.text: shall immediately cease efforts to collect the disputed debt or disputed portion of the debt from the victim of identity theft;

findings.statement: The bill allows creditors to enforce security interests on tangible personal property but prohibits collecting deficiencies from victims of identity theft.

quotes.text: may, if the disputed debt or disputed portion of the debt is secured by tangible personal property, enforce the security interest under Chapter 9, Business & Commerce Code, but may not collect or seek to collect any deficiency from the victim of identity theft.

findings.statement: The bill provides a legal recourse for creditors if they believe the identity theft claim is based on a material misrepresentation.

quotes.text: If a creditor, debt collector, or third-party debt collector has a good faith reason to believe that a consumer has disputed a consumer debt or portion of a consumer debt under this section based on a material misrepresentation that the consumer is a victim of identity theft, the creditor, debt collector, or third-party debt collector may file suit in a court of competent jurisdiction to collect the debt from the consumer.

results.bill_title: Relating to board of directors meeting locations of certain special districts.

findings.statement: The bill amends the Water Code to allow rural area water districts to conduct board meetings outside the district, provided they give notice and justification.

quotes.text: the board shall designate one or more places inside or outside the district for conducting the meetings of the board.

If the board establishes a meeting place or places outside the district, it shall give notice of the location or locations by filing a true copy of the resolution establishing the location or locations of the meeting place or places and a justification of why the meeting will not be held in the district or within 10 miles of the boundary of the district, if applicable, with the commission

findings.statement: The bill defines 'rural area district' as a district with more than half of its projected retail water or sewer connections active and not located in a county with a population of 325,000 or more.

quotes.text: "rural area district" means a district in which more than half of the district’s projected retail water or sewer connections are active and that is not wholly or partly located in a county that has a population of 325,000 or more.

findings.statement: Rural area districts must conduct at least one in-person meeting per quarter within the district or within 10 miles of its boundary, unless impractical.

quotes.text: the board shall conduct a meeting at a designated meeting location inside the district or within 10 miles of the boundary of the district at least once per quarter.

findings.statement: Rural area districts can conduct quarterly meetings via telephone or video conference, except for meetings discussing tax rates.

quotes.text: a rural area district may satisfy the requirements of Subsection (b-2) by conducting quarterly meetings by telephone conference call or video conference call. A meeting to discuss the tax rate of the district must be conducted in person.
